intro: Endoleuca pulchella, commonly known as the white sand lily, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Amaryllidaceae family and is characterized by its delicate, white, bell-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in sandy, well-drained soils and thrives in full sun to partial shade. Its leaves are narrow and grass-like, and it produces small, elongated berries that contain the seeds. Endoleuca pulchella is often found in open woodlands and is considered a rare and endangered species in its native range.
